document.docAuthor: Huang, Jia, Wang, Yalian, O’Grady, Patrick Michael, Su, Yirui & Chen, Hongwei
document.docTitle: Leucophenga valvata Huang & Wang & O’Grady & Su & Chen 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

heading.emphasis:
Leucophenga valvata Huang & Chen
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species is most similar to
L . delta
sp. nov.
in the having the postocellar setae minute ( Figs. 7A , 8M ), the mesonotum and scutellum mostly brownish yellow ( Figs. 7B , 8N ), the pleura lacking stripe above ( Figs. 7C , 8O ), and the wing mostly clouded ( Figs. 3D , 4E ), but can be distinguished from the latter in having the epandrium lacking pubescence and seta ( Fig. 36A ); surstylus caudally acute, lacking pubescence, with setae along caudal margin only ( Fig. 36A ); paramere slender, basally acute ( Fig. 36C ); aedeagus distally slightly curved ventrad, laterally with a long, apically narrow process ( Fig. 36D ).

There is intraspecific variation in abdominal tergite colour pattern in this species ( Figs. 11J–L , 12A–D ). This species is comprised of a large proportion of “shortened” ( Figs. 11J–L , 12A ) and a few “normal” specimens ( Fig. 12B ), but there is no other conspicuous intraspecific morphological variation between these two kinds of specimens. Therefore, all the specimens were identified as a single new species to avoid further confusion.

Description. Ocellar triangle dark brown, with ca. 2 or 3 setae above ocellar setae. Frons brownish ( Fig. 8M ). Orb 3 and Orb 2 parallel ( Fig. 8M ). Pedicel brownish yellow; first flagellomere yellow ( Fig. 8M ). Clypeus entirely brownish. Palpus brownish yellow ( Fig. 8M ). Postpronotal lobe brownish yellow ( Fig. 8O ). Acrostichal setulae in ca. 14–16 irregular rows ( Fig. 8N ). Katepisternum and mesopleuron mostly yellow to dark yellow ( Fig. 8O ). Wing ( Fig. 4E ): mostly clouded; costal vein between R 2+3 and R 4+5 distally with ca. 5–7 peg-like spinules on ventral surface; R 4+5 and M 1 slightly convergent distally; halter mostly yellow, with a dark yellow to dark brown patch at knob ( Fig. 8O ). Abdominal tergites dark brown to black, 2nd tergite usually yellow medially and laterally, 3rd tergite usually yellow anteriorly and laterally, entirely setigerous even in the “shortened” specimens ( Figs. 11J–L , 12A, B ), 4th tergite usually yellow anteriorly ( Figs. 11J–L , 12A–D ). Male terminalia: Cercus lacking pubescence ( Fig. 36A ). Paramere narrow apically, with ca. 7 sensilla distally ( Fig. 36C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 36.
Leucophenga valvata Huang & Chen
,
sp. nov.
, male terminalia in lateral view. A. Epandrium, surstylus, and cercus; B. Hypandrium, paramere, gonopods, aedeagus, and aedeagal apodeme; C. Paramere; D. Aedeagus. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

Etymology. From the Latin word “ valvatus ” (= valvate), referring to the aedeagus laterally with a long process.
